{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3287046,"name":"Erdem Tellioglu","username":"Erdemtel1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erdemtel1/{size}/188063_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-17T19:00:01.310Z","cooked":"

image533×849 38.2 KB

How do you mount these tubed profiles into the chassis without using an external connector part? I thought there are inner bolts probably, but if so how do you screw them since their location is pretty unaccessible from anywhere? If you can enlighten me on that one that would be very useful.

Also, normally, how do you guys mount your subsystems on to your chassis? Is there a specific way to do so that makes everything easier. I think it’s one of our biggest problems so far that it decreases the stability of our robot in a significant amount. Please enlighten me guys.

Thanks.

WestCoast Products

Tube Plugs

Square and rectangular metal tubing are among the most commonly used robot construction materials in the FIRST Robotics Competition world. Most of the time, teams will use welding or gussets connected to holes in the tubes to mount parts to tubing,...

Price: USD 2.49

REV Robotics

MAXTube Endcaps

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 5

Unfortunately, we are based on a foreign country and ordering these won’t be suitable for us. But thank you very much anyways.

Without using these tube plugs previously mentioned, there isn’t and easy way to mount 2x1 or 2x2 without some sort of external object.

For the climber we mounted this to the the bottom 2x1 using this gusset from Thrift Bot.

image802×680 104 KB

Secondly we constrained the top of the shooter by pushing a bolt through the climber and shooter assembly. This was a very wack solution but go the job done. Something else that would work would be a strong 3-D print or a custom made gusset to match the grid pattern of the shooter 2x1.

image869×582 99.5 KB

These solutions didn’t feel the best but they did work.

We usually mount with rivets and gussets if they are needed to brace.

Thank you very much, I guess we will go with custom gussets, they make the most sense in our case.

Yeah, we also use rivets in the final assembly, but before that we try to use other techniques which in our case will be custom manufacturing gussets. Thanks.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-01-17T20:43:32.727Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":129,"readers_count":128,"score":45.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":450687,"topic_slug":"how-to-mount-mechanisms-like-intake-shooter-and-climber-onto-the-chassis-properly-a-specifc-question-about-cranberry-alarms-robot","display_username":"Erdem Tellioglu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52870,"username":"FinIce","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/finice/{size}/270519_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55700,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-mount-mechanisms-like-intake-shooter-and-climber-onto-the-chassis-properly-a-specifc-question-about-cranberry-alarms-robot/450687/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3287175,"name":"Chris Mounts","username":"Chris_Mounts","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chris_mounts/{size}/6848_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-17T20:45:28.862Z","cooked":"

We’ve had good luck with 3D-printed tube ends similar in function to what WCP/REV sells. They are not as strong as the aluminum plugs, but they’ve held up well on past robots. Don’t try to mount a climber or anything with them, but they work well for a lot of other situations.
Here is a link to our current versions of blocks.
